title: 107_hr3041
content: The Act may be cited as the "Travel America Now Act of 2001". Prior to September 11, 2001, the travel and tourism industry in the United States employed over 19 million people with a payroll of $171.5 billion. In 2000, the industry generated over $582 billion in expenditures and $99.6 billion in tax revenues. Additionally, it created a $14 billion trade surplus for the country. Post-9/11, efforts are being made to ensure the safety and security of travel. Following the 9/11 attacks, efforts are being made to ensure safe travel and maintain confidence among travelers. Urgent measures are needed to support the travel industry and boost consumer spending to revive the US economy. Travel for both personal and business reasons is encouraged to keep people employed and generate cash flow. Increased consumer spending on travel and tourism is essential for revitalizing the US economy by keeping people employed and generating cash flow. Travel for personal and business reasons is encouraged to stimulate a rebound in the nation's economy. SEC. 25C. PERSONAL TRAVEL CREDIT is a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, encouraging personal travel by providing a credit. The new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, SEC. 25C, allows individuals a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred before January 1, 2002. The maximum credit is $500 for individuals and $1,000 for joint returns, covering expenses related to travel and lodging. The term 'qualified personal travel expenses' refers to reasonable expenses for travel and lodging during a qualifying personal trip within the United States, excluding expenses for meals, entertainment, amusement, or recreation. A qualifying personal trip involves travel at least 100 miles away from the taxpayer's residence and includes an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility. The term 'trip' refers to travel within the United States involving a destination at least 100 miles away from the taxpayer's residence, an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, and taken after a specific date. Personal travel expenses are not deductible if they are already deductible for a trade or business. A commercial lodging facility includes hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. Expenses related to travel for business or income production purposes are deductible. A commercial lodging facility includes hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. Special rules include denying the credit to dependents and requiring expenses to be substantiated. Expenses for business travel must be substantiated to claim a credit, and no double benefit is allowed for expenses claimed under this section. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the date of the enactment of this Act. The temporary increase in deduction for business meals and entertainment allows for 100 percent deduction for expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. SEC. 5. Net operating loss carryback for travel and tourism industry. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the year of the loss. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the year of the loss. Special rules define travel or tourism losses as the lesser of the net operating loss for the taxable year considering only income and deductions from travel or tourism businesses, or the actual net operating loss for that year. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the year of the loss. Travel or tourism business includes activities related to commercial transportation, lodging, airport operations, travel agency services, and merchandise sales within transportation facilities. The provision allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years. It includes activities related to commercial transportation, lodging, airport operations, travel agency services, and merchandise sales within transportation facilities. The provision allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years, similar to specified liability losses. Taxpayers can elect to disregard this 5-year carryback period by the due date for filing their return, with the election being irrevocable for that taxable year. The provision allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years, similar to specified liability losses. Taxpayers can elect to disregard this 5-year carryback period by the due date for filing their return, with the election being irrevocable for that taxable year. Additionally, related taxpayers within a controlled group of corporations may credit the loss against taxable income earned during the 5-year carryback period. The provision allows controlled group members to credit losses against taxable income earned in the 5-year carryback period. The amendments apply to taxable years before, on, or after the enactment date of the Act. The Act is based on Congress's power to levy taxes as outlined in the United States Constitution.
